stance_1: I eat beef four times a week
stance_2: I eat chicken three times a week
justification: Both stances are about regular meat consumption and reinforce a routine of frequent meat-eating.

stance_1: I eat beef four times a week
stance_2: I love the taste of meat
justification: Enjoying the taste of meat supports frequent beef consumption.

stance_1: I eat beef four times a week
stance_2: Meat fits easily into my routine
justification: Frequent beef consumption is explicitly described as fitting easily into the interviewee's routine.

stance_1: I eat beef four times a week
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Frequent beef eating is supported by the feeling that eating meat is normal and satisfying.

stance_1: I eat beef four times a week
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Frequent beef consumption is at odds with considering eating less meat, as the interviewee never seriously attempted to cut back.

stance_1: I eat chicken three times a week
stance_2: I love the taste of meat
justification: Enjoyment of meat taste supports frequent chicken consumption.

stance_1: I eat chicken three times a week
stance_2: Meat fits easily into my routine
justification: Frequent chicken consumption is described as fitting easily into the routine.

stance_1: I eat chicken three times a week
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Regular chicken eating is supported by meat feeling normal and satisfying.

stance_1: I eat chicken three times a week
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Frequent chicken consumption somewhat conflicts with considering eating less meat.

stance_1: I love the taste of meat
stance_2: Meat fits easily into my routine
justification: Enjoying the taste of meat makes it easier for meat to fit into the routine.

stance_1: I love the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat to get high protein
justification: Enjoyment and nutritional benefit both motivate meat consumption and can reinforce each other.

stance_1: I love the taste of meat
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: The feeling of satisfaction and normalcy is strongly linked with enjoyment of taste.

stance_1: I love the taste of meat
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Enjoying the taste of meat makes it harder to be motivated to reduce consumption; interviewee states this explicitly.

stance_1: Meat fits easily into my routine
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Meat fitting into the routine is explicitly tied to it feeling normal and satisfying.

stance_1: Meat fits easily into my routine
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Meat's easy fit into routine is a barrier to reducing consumption, as stated by the interviewee.

stance_1: I eat meat to get high protein
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Nutritional benefit and satisfaction both support regular meat-eating.

stance_1: I eat meat to get high protein
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Valuing high protein from meat may conflict with considering eating less meat.

stance_1: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Feeling that eating meat is normal and satisfying makes it more difficult to reduce consumption, as described by the interviewee.

stance_1: My social contacts eat meat regularly
stance_2: My social contacts value taste and convenience of meat
justification: Regular meat-eating among social contacts is explicitly attributed to valuing taste and convenience.

stance_1: My social contacts eat meat regularly
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Feeling that meat-eating is normal is reinforced by social contacts' regular consumption.

stance_1: My social contacts eat meat regularly
stance_2: Meat fits easily into my routine
justification: Routine meat-eating is supported by similar habits among social contacts.

stance_1: My social contacts eat meat regularly
stance_2: I sometimes consider eating less meat
justification: Having social contacts who eat meat regularly may implicitly discourage attempts to eat less meat.

stance_1: My social contacts value taste and convenience of meat
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal and satisfying
justification: Valuing taste and convenience among social contacts supports the feeling that eating meat is normal and satisfying.

stance_1: My social contacts value taste and convenience of meat
stance_2: Meat fits easily into my routine
justification: The convenience valued by social contacts reinforces the easy fit of meat into the interviewee's routine.

stance_1: I sometimes consider eating less meat
stance_2: Some of my social contacts reduce meat for health
justification: The interviewee sometimes considers eating less meat, influenced by social contacts who have tried reducing meat for health.

stance_1: My social contacts value taste and convenience of meat
stance_2: Some of my social contacts reduce meat for health
justification: Valuing taste and convenience can conflict with attempts to reduce meat for health, as described in the experiment of social contacts.
